Cooking Log
01/09/2024
chocolate brownies
Kathleen Meisinger from Ina Garten's Outrageous

Ingredients:
90g Butter
65g 60% Chocolate
60g 90% Chocolate
60g Whole Eggs
2.7g Instant Espresso Powder
5.2g Vanilla Extract
90g Sucrose (Sugar)
30g AP Flour (All-Purpose Flour)
3g Baking Powder
1.2g Sea Salt
70g Chocolate Chips (half 60% half 95%)
75g Walnuts
Method:
Melt the butter, 60% and 90% chocolate, then allow to cool slightly
In a bowl, stir (not whisk) together eggs, espresso powder, vanilla, and sugar
Stir the chocolate mixture into the egg mixture
Sift 25g flour, the baking powder, and the sea salt together.
Use the remaining 5g flour to coat the chocolate chips and walnuts (this stops them sinking)
Fold these dry ingredients into the wet mixture in 3 additions
Grease a parchment-lined 18cm round pan, and pour in the batter
Bake at 175C for 20 mins, then bang the pan to stop an air bubble forming between the brownies and the pan. Then bake around 15 minutes more, or until a toothpick comes out clean
Allow to cool before cutting
Result:
Good flavor.
Texture was not fudgy enough, too cakey. Probably due to overcooking rather than too much baking powder, as recipe is well tested by others.
12/12/2023
Pavlova
Ingredients:
For the meringue
150g egg whites
5ml white wine vinegar
10ml Vanilla Extract
300g caster sugar
25g cornflour
For the filling
1kg berries – about 6 punnets
15ml lemon
350ml double cream
Method:
Whisk the egg whites, vinegar and vanilla in a spotlessly clean bowl until soft peaks form
Add in the caster sugar gradually, while whisking and continue until stiff peak stage
Add in the cornflour and whisk again briefly on a high speed until incorporated
Line a large baking tray with parchment and 2 mounds of egg white, one a bit bigger than the other
Flatten the mounds into discs and bake at 90C. The idea is that you'll see the first signs of gold appear after about 3 hours and then that stage is complete
If it starts browning too early (within 90 mins), reduce the heat and continue
Turn the oven off and wait for it to cool – the result will be crisp without and fluffy within
Once cool, stack the meringues with cream and berries on top of each layer
Result:
Good
My meringues were still very soft inside. Not sure if this is standard or not?
10/12/2023
Chicken Liver Pate with Duck Fat
Ingredients:
120g duck fat
2/3 onion
300g chicken livers
4.5g salt
0.5tsp pepper
2 large hard-boiled eggs
1.5 teaspoons red wine vinegar
1 teaspoon whiskey, port, or sherry wine
pinch cayenne powder
melted butter for topping (optional)
Method:
Cook the onions in a third of the fat, until they are browned and beginning to caramelize, and let them drain
Add the chicken livers to the pan and season with the salt and pepper
Cook the livers, stirring often, until they are just-cooked through but still pink inside. Remove from heat
In a food processor, pulse the eggs a few times, then the remaining ingredients and puree until smooth
Taste, and adjust with salt and pepper
Press the mixture through a wide mesh sieve if you feel like it, to get it smoother
Transfer to your contained, and optionally, pour melted butter over the top to stop it discoloring
Result:
Flavour was good
Texture was a bit soft. Would substitute some of the duck fat for butter. Maybe half half

07/06/2023
Taameya Falafel
Ingredients:
250g chick peas
75g Spring onions
50g Leeks
20g Coriander
40g Parsley
3 Cloves of garlic
14g Salt
40g (started at 202g Water including cup)
1tsp Dried coriander
1tsp Cumin
Method:
Soak chickpeas overnight in 2l water with 21g salt and 7g baking soda.
Roughly chop veg and add to food processor, followed by crushed garlic, chickpeas and water. Process until forms smoothish pesto consistency.
Process in the salt.
(Tastes too salty at this point)
Beat with the whisk attachment (looks like 2 combs) of the food processor until pale, light and foamy.
Add the spices and beat again until incorporated.
Leave to rest for 2 hours.
Result:
After adding the spices and beating again, the mixture seemed to deflate somewhat. Not sure if that was really to do with the spices or a coincidence
TOO MUCH SALT. Here i used salt when soaking and salt in the mix. In total it was quite a bit too much.
28/05/2023
Teriyaki Sauce
Ingredients:
30g sake
40g mirin
18g sugar
40g soy
Method:
Add sake and mirin to the pan and boil (maybe burn is better) off the alcohol
Add the sugar and soy and reduce while stirring constantly until right consistency.
You can test for concentration with a glass of water. See sushi samurai's test
Result:
Needed a bit more sugar. Try increasing to 25g next time

22/05/2023
Yemeni Chicken
Our Yemeni Chicken
Ingredients: 6g salt
1.25g cumin powder
1g coriander powder
0.6g spicy paprika
1.75g garlic powder
2g onion powder
1g black pepper
1.25g turmeric

1 large onion
3 red pepper
5 cloves garlic
5 bay leaves
20ml olive oil
Method:
cover chicken with spices Roughly chop the onion and pepper and mix with chilli, garlic, bay, oil, and some salt. Set baking paper on foil, add the veggies, then then chicken on top and a it more oil to moisten the spices on the chicken
Wrap up and let sit an hour or more
roast at 190C fan for 80 minutes
Open it up and give it 25 minutes uncovered
Result:
Maybe not spicy enough this time, without the full chilli, and the extre paprika.
Needed a bit longer uncovered this time, i guess with the extra onions and peppers
Pretty good though

16/05/2023
Yangnyeom Chicken (Korean sticky fried chicken)
BBC
Ingredients: For the sauce 60g dark brown sugar 40g gochujang (Korean chilli paste) 30g soy sauce 10g garlic cloves, crushed 25g ginger, grated 10g sesame oil For the chicken 300g chicken breast sliced 20g ginger, finely grated 35g cornflour 4g salt 0.7g ground glack pepper Canola oil, for frying sesame seeds and sliced spring onion, to serve Method: For the sauce, blitz everything in a food processor, then let bubble gently for a few minutes in a saucepan For the chicken, mix with the ginger, then add the cornflour, salt and pepper Deep fry at 190C in the oil, then fry quickly in the sauce Serve with rice, and sprinkle the spring onion and sesame seeds over Result: Great! The sauce might have been a bit too thick, although i think it's supposed to be a sticky coating more than a sauce like sweet and sour. Maybe a little pineapple juice to loosen it could work if you want a runnier sauce.
12/05/2023
Chestnut Chocolate Cake
Ingredients:
140g butter
140g dark chocolate
5 eggs, separated
140g sugar
1g salt
2g vinegar
200g chestnuts (cooked. or chestnuts and chestnut flour - see original recipe. Chestnut flour is expensive (10chf/300g) but cheaper than chestnuts (4chf/100g). It's popular in poland (called Mąka kasztanowa) so maybe googling can find a much supplier cheaper (price in poland - 10eur/kg)
200ml cream
20g Chocolate (for garnish)
Method:
Heat oven to 180C no fan
Melt butter in a saucepan, take off the heat and melt the chocolate into it. Stir together
Whisk the egg yolks, 80g sugar, and salt until pale and thick. Stir into the warm chocolate
Whisk egg whites until fluffy. Add remaining sugar and beat until stiff peaks
Process half the chestnuts into fine powder, and half into pea sized pieces and add to the chocolate batter. Gradually fold in the egg whites, and scrape into a lined 23cm pan
Bake for 25 to 30 minutes, cool on a rack
Decorate with whipped cream, and shave chocolate over
Result:
Great
Chestnuts were slightly crunchy - maybe they could have been soaked in something - vanilla rum etc

Blintzes
Claire Saffitz | Dessert Person
Ingredients:
BLINTZES
75g flour
100g eggs
120ml milk
35g butter, melted
6g sugar
1.25g salt

FILLING

120g cream cheese, cut into 1⁄2-inch pieces, chilled
25g egg
15g sugar
1⁄4 teaspoon vanilla extract
Small Pinch salt

SAUCE
120g dried apricots (i used unsweetened), coarsely chopped
20g honey
250ml water
0.25g salt
15g lemon juice
FINAL STAGE
40g butter
Honey, for serving
Method:
Following recipe
Result:
Filling was too liquid. Maybe try ricotta or cottage cheese instead of quark. Also, cheese clothing the cream cheese wouldn't hurt, but is a pain in the ass.
In the United States, farmer cheese is simply pressed curds
07/04/2023
Basque Cheesecake Sous Vide Experiment
Ingredients: 200g cream cheese
200g double cream
4.4g cornflour
1g salt (optional)
80g caster sugar
70g eggs, beaten
Method: Beat the cream cheese, then beat in the cream, cornflour, salt, sugar and eggs unitl smooth
Divided into 3 plastic bags, and sous vide one bag at 75C, 80C and 85C respectively, until the chesecake mix reached 73C, 79C and 82C
Result: 73C - Creamy, and quite light. Almost no leakage after 12 hours
79C - in between
84C - Fudgy, felt more dense, and leaked more water
In all cases, there was a somewhat grainy appearance (despite the 73C feeling smooth). This was probably due to the cornstarch not being well enough incorporated. Maybe should dissolve it in a small amount of cream first to form a well mixed slurry and/or use an immersion blender

peas

cover with foil and bake until bottom is brown

28/02/2023
Sandwich Foccacia (Higher hydration)
YEAST ACTIVATION:
16g yeast
80g water (temp 27C)
7g honey
DOUGH:
400g caputo cuoco
8g salt
240g water
15ml oil
PAN:
5g oil
BRINE:
90ml water
30g oil
TOP:
3g Sea salt (for eating plain. if eating in sandwich, adjust saltiness to ingredients)
Details:
GOAL: Higher hydration in dough, to see effect
TOTAL FLOUR: 400g
TOTAL WATER & MILK: 320 in dough. 410 incl. brine
RATIO: 80% in dough. 102.5% incl. brine
Method:
Mix honey, water and yeast and leave 5 minutes
Mix salt into flour
Add water to the yeast mix, then stir into the flour
Kneaded by slap and fold for about 7-10 minutes, then mixed in oil
Let rise until doubled at room temp
Oil the pan, dump in the dough and finger it out, like https://youtu.be/LbmaHF13SRE?t=580 (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=347 for goal texture)
Mix the oil and water for the brine into an emulsion
Finger the dough into the corners, cover with brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until rich brown
Result:
Browned a bit before it was fully cooked but not a major issue
Best crumb so far, mix of large and small holes
27/02/2023
Sandwich Foccacia (no milk)
YEAST ACTIVATION:
16g yeast
80g water (temp 27C)
7g honey
DOUGH:
400g caputo cuoco
8g salt
170g water
14ml oil
PAN:
5-10g oil
BRINE:
90ml water
30g oil
TOP:
3g Sea salt
Details:
GOALS: Swap out milk for water
TOTAL FLOUR: 400g
TOTAL WATER: 250 in dough. 340 incl. brine
RATIO: 62.5% in dough. 85% incl. brine
Method:
Mix honey, water and yeast and leave 5 minutes
Mix salt into flour
Add water to the yeast mix, then stir into the flour
Knead until smoothish (lumpy windowpane could just about be teased out of it), and mix in oil
Let rise at room temp (600ml to 1300ml)
Oil the pan, dump in the dough and finger it out flat rather than rolling (no cleaning pin or rolling surface. less hand cleaning, like https://youtu.be/LbmaHF13SRE?t=580
Leave to rise again (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=347 for goal texture)
Mix the oil and water for the brine into an emulsion
Finger the dough into the corners, cover with brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until golden
Result:
Dough was noticeably wetter and stretchier than previous attempts
Quantity seemed better for round pan
Similar crumb to previous efforts, as in a bit too fine
400g seems good for this tray - maybe a little more like 450 would also be good. Or somehow get it to rise a bit more, so be thicker but airier
Salt was good for eating plain. If using for sandwiches, adjust saltiness to ingredients e.g. Ham and provalone might not need any salt on the foccacia

14/02/2023
Chocolate Raspberry Torte
Adapted from https://www.greatbritishchefs.com/recipes/cherry-chocolate-torte-recipe
Ingredients:
Raspberry Chocolate Torte
175g raspberries
100g dark chocolate (70g orange, 30g fleur de sel)
80g butter
50g soft dark brown sugar
10g white sugar
40g ground almonds
20g plain flour
2.5 eggs, separated
Method:
18cm pan, buttered and lined. Oven 170C no fan
Melt butter, chocolate and brown sugar together in pan, and cool a bit
Whisk egg whites to stiff peaks, adding the white sugar half way
Sprinkle flour and almonds onto egg whites, mix the yolks into the chocolate, and fold everything together. Fold in the raspberries as it is coming together
Bake 35-40 minutes
Result:
Not bad, not great
10/02/2023
Sandwich Foccacia (Increase salt to 2%)
YEAST ACTIVATION:
21g yeast
60g milk + 40g water (temp 27C)
9g honey
DOUGH:
500g caputo cuoco
10g salt
210g water
17ml oil
PAN:
5-10g oil
BRINE:
110ml water
40g oil
TOP:
2.5g Sea salt
Details:
GOALS: Increase salt levels to improve flavor, try not to let air bubble under pan
TOTAL FLOUR: 500g
TOTAL WATER & MILK: 310 in dough. 420 incl. brine
RATIO: 62% in dough. 84% incl. brine
Method:
Mix honey, milk + water and yeast and leave 5 minutes
Mix salt into flour
Add water to the yeast mix, then stir into the flour
Knead until smooth, and mix in oil
Let rise until doubled at room temp
Oil the 32cm round pan, then roll out the dough and place in the pan, and leave to rise again (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=347 for goal texture)
Mix the oil and water for the brine into an emulsion
Finger the dough into the corners, cover with brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until golden
Result:
Dough wasn't tougher with salt. If anything the opposite
Left the yeast fermenting longer - dough seemed more workable I guess as a result of this
Crumb was slightly more open - possible due to less kneading as the dough was softer
Better flavor - increased salt is good and had no downside
Had a swampy patch - need to be careful to finger it out evenly
No air bubble this time, which I think confirms it was trapped air last time
20% less dough for this pan might be better
Knowledge:
2% salt to flour weight is much better
Try to get it into the pan as evenly as possible with as little messing with it as possible
Heat oven with fan, then top bottom
09/02/2023
Sandwich Foccacia (Oil after kneading)
YEAST ACTIVATION:
21g yeast
60g milk + 40g water (temp 27C)
9g honey
DOUGH:
500g caputo cuoco
7.5g salt
210g water
17ml oil
PAN:
5-10g oil
BRINE:
110ml water
40g oil
TOP:
2.5g Sea salt
Details:
GOAL: Test if oil inhibiting gluten network development during kneading
TOTAL FLOUR: 500g
TOTAL WATER & MILK: 310 in dough. 420 incl. brine
RATIO: 62% in dough. 84% incl. brine
Method:
Mix honey, milk + water and yeast and leave 5 minutes
Mix salt into flour
Add water to the yeast mix, then stir into the flour
Knead until smooth(bored) - around 20 minutes. Got a vague windowpane (see photos), then mixed in oil
Let rise until doubled at room temp (Did this in oiled jug and it doubled in around 45 minutes)
Oil the pan, then roll out the dough and place in the pan, and leave to rise again (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=347 for goal texture)
Mix the oil and water for the brine into an emulsion
Finger the dough into the corners, cover with brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until golden
Result:
Was a bit too much dough for the 32cm round dish (750cm2).
Giant bubble formed under the entire dough and it puffed way up, into an upside down bowl shape. Has to be taken out and flipped - I guess air was trapped when i placed the dough in the tray
Reduced oiliness would leave it edible in larger amounts
Softer and airier than previous efforts, with a more breadlike structure. Bubbles were slightly too small though - would prefer a more rustic open crumb
Hard to tell about oil and brine levels - maybe a lot ended up on the oven floor due to the giant bubble
Knowledge:
Proofing correctly led to better bake
If rolling out, need to be careful about trapping air underneath when placing in the pan. Like these guys say https://youtu.be/zhjufashMj4?t=325
01/02/2023
Sandwich Foccacia
Ingredients: YEAST ACTIVATION:
25g yeast
75g milk + 50g water (mix temp 32C (should be 25?))
10g honey
DOUGH:
600g caputo cuoco
9g salt
20ml oil
190g water
PAN:
5-10g oil
BRINE:
125ml water
50g oil
TOP:
2g Sea salt
Method:
Mix honey, milk + water nad yeast and leave 5 minutes
Mix salt into flour
Add oil and water to the yeast mix, then stir into the flour
Knead until smooth, and let rise until doubled (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=292 for texture)
Oil the pan, then roll out the dough and place in the pan, and leave to rise again (see https://youtu.be/TIOcTgyuTIo?t=347 for texture)
Mix the oil and water for the brine into an emulsion
Finger the dough into the corners, cover with brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until golden
Result:
Kneading didn't show any signs of window pane test. Try more water next time
Reduced oil was better
Didn't rise - either left it too long, or gluten was poor
Knowledge:
A bit less oil is better
Overproofed dough won't rise properly
20/01/2023
Oily Foccacia
Ingredients:
YEAST ACTIVATION:
25g yeast
75g milk + 50g water (mix temp 25C)
10g honey
MAIN:
600g caputo cuoco flour
9g salt
BRINE:
100ml oil
100g water
Method:
Mix yeast activation ingredients and leave 5 minutes
knead to smooth (got no window pane during kneading)
rise until doubled
Roll out and place in oiled pan (35g oil)
leave to rise again
Mix and emulsify the brine ingredients (shaking in a bottle is good)
Finger into the corners, cover with oil/water brine, sprinkle with sea salt and bake at 250C until golden
Result:
Didn't seem to have risen enough. Probably overproofed
Crumb had small pockets
Probably needed more brine - possibly just more water
I might have been slightly too aggressive with the holes - I pushed until i felt the bottom of the pan firmly
I cooked it much hotter than fausto suggested - 270C rather than 200C. Maybe thats why the top browned so quickly while the holes were very raw - they should be soft and a bit creamy, but part of it was slightly too raw
Too oily to eat much. Could be uses for an appetizer, but eating too much gave indigestion
Knowledge:
Too much oil leaves the foccacia difficult to digest
Overproofed dough won't rise properly
31/1/2023
Rösti
Ingredients:
1000g potatoes (waxy, raclette)
9g salt
70g butter infused with a small bunch of thyme (yields about 45ml of butter as quite a bit sticks to the thyme)
Method:
Process the potatoes. 700g in large food processor, 300g in small
Rinse the potatoes briefly in water by filling bowl with water then draining
Drain and squeeze out as hard as possible in a tea towel. Mix in the salt.
Add 25ml of the melted butter to the pan at 4/6 heat, then add the potatoes and squeeze down
Fry the rösti on a relatively low heat until browned underneat
Drizzle and brush with 20ml of the thyme butter, then flip and fry again until the second side is also brown.
The potatoes are find of frying/steaming/baking all at the same time
Served plain, and with Creme fraiche and chives
Result:
Texture was similar to last time - still a bit fall aparty
Thyme was a good addition
Probably needed a little more butter on the second side. It dissappeared into the potato a bit
Was good with creme fraiche and chives
Changes next time:
Grate potatoes, and don't rinse
25/1/2023
Rösti
Ingredients:
1000g potatoes (waxy, raclette)
9g salt
40g butter
Method:
Grate or Process the potatoes. Large side of the grater, or large food processor grater. The food processor gives potatoes a bit more like julienne texture, which is probably not quite as good, but it is fast.
Rinse the potatoes briefly in water then drain and squeeze out in a tea towel. Mix in the salt.
Fry the rösti on a relatively low heat until browning underneath. Transfer to a 170C oven and bake for 15-20 minutes.
Flip and fry again until the second side is also brown.
The potatoes are find of frying/steaming/baking all at the same time
Result:
Very decent.
The texture was less like a solid cake, and wanted to fall apart a bit too much. I think from the food processor, but maybe washing the starch out wasn't really needed.
Next time would try it just in the pan. Maybe covered.

19/1/2023
Battered Fish
Ingredients:
BATTER:
50g cornflour
150g flour
270ml beer
3g salt
15g baking powder
FISH:
70g Salt
700ml Water
350g fish
1 lemon
little flour for dusting
Method:
Chill all the batter ingredients for an hour in the freezer.
Whisk the salt into the water until dissolved, then add the chopped up lemon and the fish. Brine for 10 minutes, then take out.
Heat oil to 190C
Make the batter by whisking everything except the beer together so they're evenly distributed. Add the beer, and combine with as little movement as possible.
Flour the fish lightly, then dip in the batter and straight into the oil
While it fries, you can add extra batter. I do this by using a spider to lift the fish quickly above the oil and drizzling more batter over with a spoon
Drain on a rack
Result:
Super bubbly batter from the baking powder and beer, that gave a very crispy result.
18/1/2023
Basque Cheesecake
The Guardian
Ingredients: 500g cream cheese, room temp
200g creme fraiche, room temp
210g caster sugar
2.5g salt (optional)
3.5 eggs, beaten
11g cornflour
50ml double cream
Method:
Beat the cheese with a wooden spoon until soft, the beat in, in order, creme fraiche, sugar & salt, eggs (one at a time)
Dissolve the cornflour in some of the double cream - it's easier to start with a little and form a paste, and then gradually add the cream. Beat this cream and cornflour into the cream cheese mix
You're aiming to get no air bubbles, so the final cheesecake has a dense texture.
(It should also be possible to mix with an immersion blender instead of a wooden spoon, as long as it's fully submerged so it doesn't add air)
Line an 18cm pan with baking paper - one piece for the base and one for the sides. The piece used for the side should extend well above the sides of the pan as the mixture may double in size during cooking
Cooked at 220C fan
Taken out with lowest temperature (in the middle of the middle) at 50C. Not sure how long it took
Result:
Generally the result was very good.
Opening the oven to check the temp didn't seem to have and bad side effect. It sunk a bit, but then rose again. It sinks anyway while cooling.
Took it out when it was mostly chestnut brown and getting to the point of burnt in a few places. Some people burn it more but it doesn't seem to taste better in the burnt places. I'd stick to deep chestnut brown.
Next Time:
Would take it out slightly earlier - maybe at 45C. The middle was still a bit creamy, but not as much as some i've seen. In this case the oven temperature would need to be a little higher to get it browned when the middle is 45C
Would try buttering the interior surface of the bottom baking paper to see if that allows it to be removed after cooling
Would try a little more flour next time, as it had a hint of weeping at the base after cooling.
Other possible things to tweak would include using 250ml double cream instead of 50ml double cream and 200g creme fraiche (the original uses only double)
Would also he interesting to hang the cheese in cheesecloth to remove some of the moisture
06/01/2023
Creme Dimplomat (for Roscon de Reyes)
Encore un Gateau
More tips are available at https://www.masterclass.com/articles/diplomat-cream-recipe

Ingredients:
5 sheets of gelatine (This is only needed if it should be reasonably cuttable. For eclairs for example it wouldn't be necessary)
120g egg yolks
200g caster sugar
75g cornflour
4 vanilla pods
750ml whole milk
600ml very cold full cream
Method:
Creme Pat:
Add the vanilla seeds and pods to the milk, bring to the boil, and leave to steep 30 minutes.
Soak the gelatine leaves in cold water.
Whisk the egg yolks with the caster sugar, then whisk in the cornflour.
Reheat the milk, remove the vanilla pods, and pour over the egg mixture while whisking.
Pour the mixture back into the saucepan, and heat on medium until it boils, stirring constantly.
Pour the custard into a clean dish, add the softened gelatine, and whisk until thoroghly incorporated.
Cover with cling film, and refrigerate until completely chilled.
Prepare the Creme Diplomat:
Whip the very cold full cream to soft peaks
Beat the creme pat to soften, then fold in the whipped cream
Result:

Katsu Sandwich
joshuaweissman.com
Ingredients:
Slaw:
1/3 small green cabbage, thinly sliced
3 green onions, thinly sliced
1/2 clove of garlic
30ml lemon, and zest of 1/4
60g mayonnaise
salt and pepper

Tonkatsu Sauce:
125g ketchup
40g oyster sauce
60g Worcestershire sauce
40g sugar

Katsu:
2 pork loin chops
flour
1 egg
1 tablespoon (12g) water
100g breadcrumbs (should be panko)
Salt to taste
Method:
Slaw: Mix it all up and leave it for a bit. Taste for salt
Sauce: Mix it all up in a saucepan, and heat until the sugar dissolves
Katsu: Beat your meat until around 1cm thick, the salt, flour, egg, and breadcrumb it. Deep fry at 180C until golden (check internal temp too)
Serving: Bread, mayo, meat, slaw, tonkatsu sauce, bread
Result:
Gooooood.

24/09/2022
Creme Brulee
Ingredients:
75ml milk
1g salt
1 vanilla bean
6 egg yolks
70g white sugar
375ml full cream
brown sugar
Method:
Heat the milk with the salt and vanilla and leave to infuse (milk takes flavor better than cream)
Beat the egg yolks, white sugar and cream together
Make it into a custard, heating until it just reaches 80C
Bake in a bain marie in the oven at 150C for about 90 minutes, until the centre is still a little wobbly. Then chill thoroughly
Pour way too much brown sugar on the top, then tip off the excess
Blowtorch it to form a crust, few black spots is ok
Result:
The cream wasn't quite as smooth as i would have liked. Next time try not actually making a custard
The crust was a little thicker than i'd have liked. Maybe finer sugar would do it
To get the ratio of cream to crust right, you want about 2cm of ream and a thin crust

Dacquoise
Ingredients:
150 egg whites
200g granulated sugar
300g ground almonds and hazelnuts
200g powdered sugar
75g cocoa powder
1g salt
Method:
Beat the egg whites until fluffy, then beat in the granulated sugar until the mixture is glossy and you get floppy peaks.
Mix the almond flour, powdered sugar, cocoa powder, and salt.
Fold the dry ingredients into the eggs until you get a mousse-like consistency.
Spread on a papered baking sheet
Cover a sheet pan with the dough, and let it sit for a half hour.

Heat the oven to 180 C and bake until the meringues start to crack, about 15 minutes.
Cool completely before filling.
Result:
First impression - seems too sweet, from tasting dough
Very lumpy. Should use finer ground nuts

21/05/2022
Chocolate & Apricot Cake 2
Ingredients: 50g dried unsweetened apricots 35ml vanilla rum 96g unsalted butter, softened 75g jacutinga sugar 60g white sugar 2 egg yolks 1 egg white 10g icing sugar 130g ground almonds 1.25 tsp baking powder 0.33 teaspoon salt 70g 87% chocolate, frozen, then blitzed until sandy texture 30g cocoa powder Method: Chop and blitz the apricots, and soak in the rum overnight. After they've soaked squeeze out the excess rum
Cream the butter and sugars, then gradually beat in the egg yolks
Combine the almonds, baking powder, salt and chocolate and mix well. Mix in the apricots, then stir into the batter
Beat the egg whites until stiff, adding the icing sugar towards the end. Fold into the previous mixture, keeping as much air as possible
Baked for 55 minutes at 150C fan
Result: Better than the last attempt, but still a bit sour
More chocoaltey than last attempt which was good, and not so wet. Attribute this to the increased almonds and reduced butter, and maybe the baking powder helped too
Probably a bit too cocoa-ey. Maybe more chocolate could be added instead of the cocoa (my worry was that chocolate was making it wetter, but that seems to be less of an issue here)
Next time, would try with sweetened apricots rather than the sour ones, 20g cocoa, and 90g chocolate

Chocolate & Apricot Mothers Day Cake
Ingredients: 70g dried unsweetened apricots 50ml vanilla rum 125g unsalted butter, softened 60g jacutinga sugar 60g white sugar 3 egg yolks 2 egg whites 10g icing sugar 100g ground almonds 0.5tsp baking powder 0.33 teaspoon salt 60g 80% chocolate, frozen, then blitzed until sandy texture Method: Chop and blitz the apricots, and soak in the rum

16/04/2022
Flour Tortilla Test
Joshua Weissman
Ingredients: Dough according to the recipe
175g flour
3g fine sea salt
3g baking powder
20g pork lard
90ml warm water

Method: Mixed ingredients. Kneaded half, didn't knead the rest
All were made from the same dough, and all were rolled through the pasta roller down to second thinnest setting
Cooked some immediately, left some to rest 30 minutes, some 90 minutes
Rolled one immediately, and left it 90 minutes in the fridge
Result:
Knead No Knead
No Rest Didn't rise much. More like a cracker. Not good As with the no knead, it was more like a cracker. Not good
Rested 30 minutes Better Rise. Mostly medium size bubbles Puffed up well
Rested 90 minutes Puffed up well. Probably looked a bit nicer than the no knead, but not much difference eating Decent rise, but looked a bit more ragged than the kneaded one

The bread that was rolled and then left to rest didn't rise at all

Conclusions:
  • It's probably worth a quick knead for appearance
  • 30 minutes is around the lower limit for resting, but in general longer is better
  • Don't roll until before cooking
  • The second thinnest setting on the pasta roller is a bit too thin

18/02/2021
Cakey Scones
Ingredients: 60g cake flour
100g plain flour
1g salt
5g baking powder
60g salted butter, grated in
70ml milk
20ml cream
45g caster sugar
2ml vanilla extract
20g beaten egg
Method: Mix the flours, salt and baking powder, then grate in the butter and rub it in until the texture is like breadcrumbs
Whisk the milk, cream, sugar, vanilla and egg together, then add to the dry mix (leaving a lttle behind for brushing on the scone later)
Combine, with as little mixing as possible, to leave a wet dough
Put on a baking sheet with baking paper, brush the top with the remaining liqued, and bake at 180C for about 20 minutes, until well browned
Result: Really good - a bit sweeter, richer and more cakey than a british scone
Also added a little lemon zest, orange would be good too, as would dried fruits or nuts

08/02/2021
Parmigiana di Melanzane
Ingredients: 700g aubergines
20g salt
2l water
700ml olive oil
150g mozzarella, drained, sliced, and squeezed out a bit
120g Scamorza, thinly sliced
60g parmesan
350g tomato ragu
15g basil leaves
Method: Slice the aubergines in about 6mm slices
Dissolve the salt in the water, then soak the aubergines for about an hour
Drain the aubergines and squeeze the water out of the well
Heat the oil to 180C, and fry the aubergine slices in small batches (about 4 slices at a time) so the oil doesn't cool
Spread a layer of tomato ragu on the dish as the first layer
Now add a layer of aubergines. Calculate how many layers you're gonna do based on how many slices you used for the first, and roughly divide up the mozzarella, scamorza, parmesan basil, and tomato ragu. You'll need a bit extra ragu and cheese for the top layer
Scatter mozzarella, scamorza, basil leaves, parmesan and a few blobs of tomato ragu on the aubergines, add another layer of aubergines
Repeat the layering until all the aubergines are used up
Top with a thin layer of ragu to protect the aubergines from the oven, and scatter with remaining cheese
Bake for 10 mins at 180C fan, and then at 130C until done
Result: Not bad
Probably better with a more basic tomato ragu, as the texture of the meaty bits was a bit annoying. And in general, the meatiness was a bit much.
Scamorza (especially on top) was a bit chewier than I would have wanted - I'd reduce it to 70g, roughly grate it, and not have any on the top
10g basil would be enough

Raspberry Tirumisu
Ingredients: 500g frozen raspberries 3 egg whites 90g sugar 4 egg yolks 1tsp vanilla extract 375g mascarpone 20g Simple Syrup (50:50 water sugar by weight) 12 ladyfinger biscuits Method: Leave the raspberries to thaw completely in a sieve over a bowl. Overnight Have the eggs and mascarpone in the fridge overnight, and take out 20 minutes before starting to make the tiramisu In a bowl, whisk the egg whites until almost stiff. Add 20g sugar, and continue whisking until stiff In a second bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the remaining sugar intil thick and pale. Whisk in the vanilla In a third bowl, whip the mascarpone a little, on the slowest speed to soften it up, so it will combine more easily with the other ingredients Add the egg yolk mix into the mascarpone, and whisk at the slowest setting until smoothly combined Fold in the egg whites Mix the juice from the raspberries with the simple syrup. Do this to taste and don't make it too sweet Dunk the ladyfingers in the juice until they soak a decent amount of it. It took about 10 seconds each side, as they wouldnt fully submerge. Layer up mascarpone mix, then biscuits, then half the raspberries. Repeat, top with the rest of the mascarpone mix Sprinkle with lime leaf powder (freeze dried raspberries would also work) Result: Really good
Could have some extra accent flavor - lime or orange maybe, or ispahan

Roast Potatoes
Ingredients: 3 medium Potatoes - Jelly variety
1/2 tsp baking powder
1 liter cold water
salt
50ml Olive Oil
Method: Day 1
Peel the potatoes and rinsed 5 minutes in cold water to remove starch (wasn't obvious that much was coming out - might depend on variety). Add them to the cold water along with the baking soda and salt
Cook until soft in the middle, drain, rough up a bit, set on a rack and leave to dry overnight outside in the cold
Day 2
Heat the oven, with a tray inside to 240C
Heat the oil in a frying pan until it starts to smoke, then fry the potatoes in there for a bit until starting to brown
Put in the oven, and roast until well browned
Result: Good. 7/10
Maybe could be boiled a bit less, so they could be roughed up more, and then given more time in the oven
Maybe the frying pan bit is unnecessary - Sorted chef just coat the in oil and fat cold and whacks them in the oven (240 to start them turned down)

Spaghetti al Limone
Ingredients: lemon stock - 1.5l water, shells of 3 lemons (after juicing), 6 lime leaves. Water heated to i guess 70C, then left overnight to steep. Reduced to 750ml
200g spaghetti
10g oil
25g butter
30g parmesan, finely grated
drizzle of lemon oil - (made from zest of 1 lemon, blitzed to death with 40ml rapeseed oil, then passed through a fine sieve)
Method: Cook the spaghetti in a frying pan with the lemon stock and some salt.
Be gentle with it until the spaghetti absorbs enough water to be flexible.
Basically, cook it like a risotto, adding more water if you need, until the spaghetti is cooked, and a small amount of starchy liquid is left
Like finishing a risotto - Remove from the heat, then stir in the cheese and butter (oil is another option) to get a creamy consistency
Thin the sauce with some water or more lemon stock if needed
Serve with black pepper and with a little of the lemon oil
Result: Horribly bitter from the lemon piths. Either piths from sorrento lemons taste a lot better, or its a mistake to use anything more than the zest

Roasted Almond Ice Cream
Ingredients:
150g almonds
20g white sugar
15g butter
260ml milk
4 egg yolks
100g white sugar
1.5g salt
260ml full cream
15ml vanilla rum
Method:
Heat the oven to 170C. Roast the almonds until they start to brown slightly, then mix with the sugar and butter and roast for another 10 minutes. Leave to cool, then chop roughly
Put the milk in a pan and heat until simmering
Whisk the egg yolks, sugar and salt together, then mix in the milk
Put back in the pan, and reheat until it forms a thin custard
Mix in the cream, vanilla, and almonds
Chill thoroughly and then churn
Result:
Good

Lemon & Basil Ice Cream
By Me
Ingredients:
105g sugar
22g basil (weight of leaves and stems)
1 tbsp cornflour
2 eggs
juice of 1 lemon
zest of 1 lemon
250g full cream
15ml limoncello
1.5g salt
Method:
mortar and pestle the basil and half the sugar
Put cornflour, eggs, lemon juice and zest in a saucepan
Heat over medium until it thickens and starts bubbling. Let it bubble for another 30 seconds
Strain it into the cream and limoncello, then mix, add in the basil sugar
Taste for salt, then chill and churn
Result:

30/08/2021
Swedish Lace Cookies
Ingredients:
60g butter
100g porridge oats
120g granulated light brown sugar
1 egg
15g flour
1tsp baking powder
1g salt

Method:
Makes 12 biscuits
Melt the butter and mix in the porridge oats, followed by the flour, baking powder and salt
Whisk the egg and sugar together until pale and thick
Fold the oats into the egg
Line a baking sheet with parchment, and spoon out the mix. You should have 6 biscuits per baking sheet, and they spread a lot
Bake at 170C until there is a midium brown ring around the edge of each biscuit. About 6-8 minutes
Take out, slide sheet off pan, and allow to cool
Result:
Better.
Best cooked reasonably near the bottom, to ensure the bottom of the cookie crisps up and releases from the paper before the top gets overdone

26/08/2021
Kourabiedes
Stelios Parliaros
Ingredients:
175g butter preferably clear
70g unpeeled almonds
0.40 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp vanilla powder
60g powdered sugar & extra for sprinkling
25g vanilla rum
350g flour
Method:
Roast the almonds at 160C for about 13 minutes (longer than suggested). Leave them to cool well and bash them in a mortar and pestle. Left reasonably big pieces, up to half a nut
Beat the butter at high speed for 10 minutes, until white and fluffy. More beating more better
Add the sugar and beat again for 10 minutes
Mix the flour and baking powder, and add gradually while beating slowly
Finally add the almonds and rum and mix in
Divide the dough into 16 balls and squish the top a bit. Bake on greaseproof paperat 170C for 20-30 minutes, until just colored
Remove from the oven, cool thoroughly and roll them in a bowl of icing sugar to cover well. It's important they cool befoer the sugar goes on
Sprinkle extra icing sugar when serving them
Notes:
They shouldn't brown much
Initially, more beating more better
Clarified butter may be better
Result:
Not bad, but not revolutionary either
Some more nuts would improve it - maybe 100g, and more alcohol or vanilla. Maybe a little orange zest would be goods
Maybe the goats butter would have a stronger flavor

Ta'ameya - Egyptian Falafel
Middle Eats
Ingredients:
Taameya Batter
200g Split Fava beans
50g Spring Onions
50g Leeks
30g Coriander
30g Parsley
2 Cloves of garlic
1 Tsp Dried Coriander
3/4 Tsp Cumin
1/4 Tsp Cayenne
9g salt
1l vegetable oil for frying
Topping
1 tbsp Coriander seeds
1 tbsp Sesame seeds

Method:
Chopped everything in the mini food processor, then whipped it with the electric whisk
Making the balls either by spooning straight into the oil or using the method here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7RLQfCXdr-g. Both were good and the video method was actually quite easy
Tried making balls by rolling the dough in the hand, but the result was not as light and the outside less crispy

Result:
Could have had a little more spice in the mix, but maybe it's not supposed to
Tiny bit more salt would also be good
Try half a teaspoon black pepper
Try with some tahini in the mix - 20g
Try with baking soda (1 tsp) to imcrease fluffiness

10/08/2021
Sticky Toffee Pudding
Guardian
Ingredients:
Sauce:
55g unsalted butter
30g raw brown sugar
30g light brown sugar
70ml double cream
1g salt
Pudding:
100g dates, roughly chopped
1/2 tsp bicarbonate of soda
150ml boiling water
25g unsalted butter, softened
40g raw brown sugar
40g light brown sugar
1 egg
15ml vanilla rum
90g flour
1g salt
1/2 tsp baking powder
Pinch of ground cloves
Method:
Add the dates and baking soda to the boiling water. Bring to the boil, then leave to sit until the dates soften a bit
Sauce:
Meanwhile, make the sauce. Add everything to a pan and bring to the boil, then allow to bubble for a few minutes until it thickens
Butter a 25*10cm pan, and pour half the sauce in the bottom and freeze
Pudding:
Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, then add the egg and vanilla and beat well
Blend the softened dates to a puree, and stir into the mix
Mix the flour, salt, baking powder and cloves together, and fold into the mix
Take the pan out of the freezer, and pour the cake batter in
Bake at 170C until just firm to the touch, about 30 minutes
Poke holes in the cake with a skewer, and pour the remaining sauce over (needed to reheat)
Grill or a few minutes, without burning

Result:
Much better. The cake was a lot more moist

09/08/2021
Black Bean Soup
Ingredients:
200g dried or 500g cooked black beans
1 teaspoon salt
2 bay leaves
2 cloves garlic
1 medium onion
1 green or red pepper
1 lime
2 Chipotles in adobo
400ml chicken stock
salt
100g sour cream
half an avocado

Method:
If using dried beans, simmer them for about 2 hours until tender with 1 liter of water, 2 bay leaves and 1 tsp salt
Discard the bay leaves, and keep the beans, garlic clove and about 200ml of the cooking water
Fry the onion and pepper in a little oil for about 5 minutes until it softens
Crush the garlic and add to the pan, along with the chipotles and the zest of the lime. Fry for another minute or so, until softened a bit but not browned
Add the beans, bean cooking water and stock. Simmer for 15 minutes
Blend until smooth
Serve with a dollop of sour cream
Dice the avocado and mix with the juice of the lime. Add on top of the sour cream, along with a little flaky salt

Result:
Good
Add coriander to soup

Sticky Toffee Pudding
Francis Coulson
Ingredients:
40g butter, softened
120g dates, roughly chopped
0.75 teaspoon baking soda
120g caster sugar
1.5 eggs
2 teaspoon vanilla rum
120g flour
1 teaspoon baking powder
150ml double cream
25g (2 oz) demerara sugar
10g black treacle

Method:
Boil the dates in 200ml water until soft. Add the baking soda and stir
Cream the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy, then add the eggs and beat well
Mix in the date mixture and vanilla
Mix the flour and baking powder together, and fold into the mix
Butter a 20x10cm baking tim and pour the cake batter in
Bake until just firm to the touch, about 30 minutes
To make the sauce, boil the cream, sugar and treacle (molasses) together
Cover the sponge with sauce (there will be some left over), then grill until it begins to bubble
Cut into squares, and serve with the remaining sauce and a scoop of vanilla ice cream

Result:
Sponge was not dry, but not quite as squidgy as i'd have liked - a bit too airy

24/06/2021
Kvaefjordkake
North Wild Kitchen
Ingredients:
40g butter
40g granulated sugar
1.5 egg yolks
20ml milk
50g all-purpose flour
½ teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon vanilla sugar

For the meringue:
1.5 egg whites
70g granulated sugar
20g sliced almonds

For the filling:
Creme pat with 200ml milk
150ml full cream

Method:
Beat the butter and sugar together until light and fluffy. Add the egg yolks one at a time, while whisking, and add in the milk.
Combine the flour, baking powder, and vanilla sugar in a medium bowl and add this to the mixture, whisking until combined.

In a clean, large stand mixer set to medium-low or a large mixing bowl whisk together the egg whites until foamy. Add the sugar a little at a time and continue to whisk until glossy, stiff peaks form.

Line the baking tin, spread the cake batter over the bottom of it, then top with the meringue and then the almonds.

Gently pour the meringue evenly over the batter with a rubber spatula
Place in the middle rack of the oven and bake until the meringue is dry and lightly golden (about 20 minutes)

Make the creme pat and leave to chill. Then whip the cream, and gradually whip into the chilled creme pat

Allow the cake to cool before filling

Result:
Pretty good. Especially the creme diplomat
I used vanilla rum as vanilla essence and sugar, and probably didn't have enough vanilla flavor

Coffee Cake
My Recipe
Ingredients:
CAKE
125g walnuts
125g hazelnuts

200g brown sugar
2 eggs
1 egg yolk

1 tsp baking powder

100ml oil
ICING
160g icing sugar
80g butter
1 teaspoon instant coffee
1 tsp vanilla rum

Method:

One Pot Chicken with Coconut Rice
Ingredients:
30g plain yogurt
5g salt
20g ginger
5 cloves garlic
1 tsp turmeric
0.75 tsp chili powder
2 chicken legs, without skin

3 tbsp cooking oil
1 sliced onion
2 bay leaves
3g salt
150g basmati rice
150ml coconut milk, heated
150ml hot water
½ tsp ground coriander
5g fresh coriander

Method:
Blend the yogurt, salt, ginger, garlic, turmeric and chili powder to make a smooth marinade
Split the chicken into thighs and drumsticks, smother with the marinade and leave for 30 minutes
Fry the chicken in the oil over medium high heat until slightly browned (no neet to remove the marinade from the chicken)s
Remove from pan, the fry the onion alog with the bay in the same pan
Add the salt, rice, coconut milk and water. Place the chicken on top, then bring to boil, cover, turn heat right down and cook for about 15 minutes until the rice is done
Stir in the ground coriander and coriander

Result:
Great! Could also have some green vegetables in there - beans, peas etc.

Croquetas with Mushroom
Ingredients
1630ml milk
5 bay leaves
6 cloves
140g butter
2/3 large onion
225g mushrooms
120g flour
1ml ground white pepper
14g salt
1tsp powdered cepes
2 eggs
200 g breadcrumbs
vegetable oil for deep-frying

Method:
Bring milk to the boil along with bay and cloves, then leave to infuse
In a separate pan, fry the onion in butter until soft, then add the mushrooms and fry another few minutes
Add the flour, and fry a few minutes more
Add the milk, and pepper
Weigh, then cook, stirring and scraping the base of the saucepan every other minute, until 1250g remains in the pan
Leave to chill overnight, thn ball, flour, egg, breadcrumb, and fry at 190C until brown

Result:
Good. Salt was about right

30/4/2021
Choux Pastry
French Cooking Academy
Ingredients:
200ml water
80g butter
5g sugar
2g salt
170g eggs
1 egg (for the glazing)
100g white bread flour

Method:
Put the water, butter, sugar and salt in a saucepan, bring to the simmer
Take off the heat, dump the flour in, and quickly whisk together until combined
Place back on a moderate heat, and cook while stirring until a crust forms over the bottom of the saucepan
Leave to cool a bit (you can beat it a bit to speed this up), then beat in the eggs one at a time (it will split and then come together as you add each egg). You should add the egg slowly toward the end until it reaches the correct consistency. The correct consistency occurs has been reached when you can hold a big spoonful sidewards, and it falls off slowly in a single large blob
Pipe into the desired shape
Knock off any tips by wetting your finger and poking them, before glazing with the final beaten egg
Cook at 200C fan for about 30 minutes, until well browned

Result:
Great.
There are a lot of variations in this:
  • butter can be between 50% and 100% of the flour weight (eclair de genie suggests 100%). More butter gives more crispness and flavor, although maybe more softness too (just my theory)
  • it's more common to use half milk, half water (eclair de genie). More milk is said to give flavour and color, while more water should give a crisper result
  • sugar is not standard, but i guess it works for sweet recipes

Other Notes:
  • bread flour likely makes it crisper
  • weights are more important than number of eggs
  • judging based on consistency is more important than exact weight of eggs etc.
  • resting choux after piping is a good thing - 15 or 20 minutes is enough. It forms a slight crust which tends to give a more even rise
  • to get more evenly browned choux, you can take it out of the oven 5 minutes before it's done, let it cool, and then put it back in to finish
  • poking a few holes after baking is done will help release steam and give a crisper result
  • choux that has gone soft can be refreshed by quickly baking again
  • securing your paper with a dot of pastry in each corner makes piping a lot easier
  • a large many pointed star tip is typically used for piping eclairs
  • christophe adam uses vanilla in the pastry (8g liquid per 100g flour)
See also
  • https://www.parisiennefarmgirl.com/today-in-kitchen-pierre-hermes/
  • https://foodcrumbles.com/the-science-of-choux-pastry-in-profiteroles/
  • https://www.theflavorbender.com/how-to-make-perfect-choux-pastry

24/04/2021
Bitter Lemon Sorbet
Ingredients:
3 lemons
100g sugar
350ml water

Method:
Chop up half a lemon and pick out the seeds, put in a blender (so, the pith, zest and flesh)
Zest the remaining lemons and put the zest in a saucepan with the sugar and 100ml of the water. Bring to the boil to make a syrup
Juice the remaining lemons, and put the juice in the blender along with the remaining 250ml water
Once you have your syrup, add that to the blender also, and blend thoroughly until very smooth
Chill, and churn

Result:
Not so smooth as it coud be. Probably better to do the blending with less liquid

Chill the mix, and then churn

24/3/2021
Croquetas de Jamon
Ingredients (for 3 people)
815ml milk
2 bay leaves
3 cloves
70g butter
1/3 large onion
110g serrano ham
60g flour
1/4 nutmeg, grated
pinch of ground white pepper
5.6g salt
1 egg
100 g breadcrumbs
Light olive oil or vegetable oil for deep-frying

Method:
Bring milk to the boil along with bay and cloves, then leave to infuse
In a separate pan, fry the onion in butter until soft, then add the ham and fry another minute
Add the flour, and fry a few minutes more
Add the milk, nutmeg, and pepper and cook stirring constantly until well thickened, losing around 300g ( 286g to be exact )
Whisk the egg yolks, and then mix a little of the bechamel into them before adding back into the rest of the bechamel
content weight 1009g
40g eaten
final weight 3350g
final content weight 683g
weight evaporated 286g

Result:
They ended up too salty, but more or less everything else was good
Try 3g salt next time (although it will always depends a bit on the ham)
Info: Serrano ham is about 5% salt - so 110g = 5.5g salt
Info: Cooked ham is about 2.5% salt - so 110g = 5.5g salt

Chicken Liver Pate
Ingredients:
450g chicken livers, cleaned
180g butter, diced
1 shallot, finely chopped
1 tsp thyme leaves, finely chopped
90ml cognac
40ml double cream
6g tsp salt
1/3 tsp ground allspice
1/3 tsp ground ginger
3 tsp green peppercorns

Method:
Fry shallots and thyme with a knob of the butter until soft, then empty into blender
Fry chicken livers quickly until browned, but very pink inside. Add to blender
Add cognac to pan and reduce to syrup. Add to the blender
Add the spices, salt, cream and remaining butter to the blender
Blend until smooth, then sieve
Fold in the peppercorns and transfer to final dish

Result:
Much better. Consistency was much better because of the extra butter and less cream
Cognac is much better than grand marnier
Peppercorns are good, but maybe 2 teaspoons would be enough

03/03/2021
Burnt orange ice cream
Epicurious
Ingredients:
2 oranges (medium blond)
40g butter
300g sugar
500ml cream
150ml milk
2 egg yolks
2tsp vanilla
1.5g salt

Method:
Soften butter and rub over oranges
Dip oranges in sugar
Add 80g sugar to 25*20cm tray, and put oranges on top. Keep rest of sugar aside
Bake at 210 until sugar browning
Remove and reserve the sugar, then quarter the oranges and return them to oven until they get quite dark brown (chocolatey shade)
Scoop out the flesh of one orange and discard
Blend the sugar from the oven, the orange and orange peel, and the remaining sugar, then pass through a sieve
Heat the puree in a saucepan until bubbling, beat remaining ingredients together in a bowl, and then add the pure and whisk together
Chill and freeze

Result:
Not amazing, but interesting and pretty good. Bitter, but not too bitter - might go well with something very sweet

16/02/2021
Shortcrust Pastry
Ingredients:
300g flour
150g butter
5.5g salt (3/4tsp)
45g water

Method:
Cubed butter, abd mixed with flour and salt. Returned to fridge to chill along with mini food processor
Processed in 2 batches until resembling breadcrumbs
Sprinkle the wateronto the mix, mix and chop around with a spoon, before forming into a relatively dry dough by hand
Leave to relax for 30 minutes
Blind bake with rice 20 minutes
Egg wash and bake 10 minutes

Result:
Good

15/12/2020
Dashi
Ingredients:
1 liter water
10 * 12cm kombu
30g bonito flakes


Method:
Kombu soaked in the water overnight
The water and kombu are then heated to 75C and then the kombu is removed
The water is then brought just to the boil, and removed from the heat
Bonito is then added, stirred, left for five minutes and then strained to leave the dashi

Result:
Much better than previous efforts

09/12/2020
Miso Soup
Hiroyuki Terada
Ingredients:
2 liters water
10 * 12cm kombu
40g bonito flakes
100g miso paste (caramel color) (optional)
20ml mirin
tofu
dried wakame

Method:
Heat cold water with kombu until boiling
Turn off heat, remove kombu, add bonito, let steep for 2 minutes then strain. Now you have dashi
Whisk the miso paste into the dashi and add the mirin
Serve with some tofu cubes and about half a teaspoon dried wakame per cup

Result:
Not bad, but could have been a bit stronger flavor. Maybe needed some extra kombu in the dashi, and letting the bonito flakes simmer in it for a while (not much though, as most recipes don't, or just very briefly)
Some suggest soaking the kombu in the water overnight before making the dashi
note: shouldn't let the water boil when the kombu is in the water. Take it out just before boiling (this is in all the recipes, and seems important)

02/12/2020
Mandy Lee's Crispy Whole Fried Chicken
Mandy Lee on Youtube
Ingredients:
Chicken
Salt
butter
garlic
thyme

Method:
Flatten chicken - wing tips off, wishbone out, remove breast bone, cut around remaining bones. Basically get as flat as possible and o that all skin is on one side so it can be fried on that
Salt with 1% salt by weight, and leave in fridge
Put skin side down in a cold pan, and slowly fry over medium-low heat until skin is super golden crispy and chicken is nearly cooked through
Flip it, and add butter, garlic and thyme, and continue frying until cooked through

Result:
Very crispy skin, good flavor and moist

My Recipe
Ingredients:

100g sugar

zest of half an orange
2.5 sheets gelatine

Method:

Leave to set overnight

Result:

18/11/2020
Cream Cheese Icing (with dehydrated Migros Cream Cheese)
My Recipe
Ingredients:
Migros Cream Cheese

Method:
Hung 244g of Migros Cream Cheese in cheesecloth

After 6 hours with some light squeezing, the cheese had lost 50g water or 20%
New nutritional info per 100g
Fett 35g
Kohlenhydrate 5.6g
davon Zucker 5.1g
Eiweiss 5.8g

After 18 hours with some light squeezing, the cheese had lost 80g water or 33%
New nutritional info per 100g
Fett 42g
Kohlenhydrate 6.4g
davon Zucker 6.1g
Eiweiss 6.9g

Result:
Best result so far with this icing - much thicker than previous attempts.
Next time would try with less sugar.

15/11/2020
Tamagoyaki (Japanese sushi omelette, baked)
myrecipes.com
Ingredients:
5 eggs
45ml dashi
60ml cream
20g brown sugar
10ml light soy sauce (should be white, a.k.a. shiro)

Method:

Remix, before putting in baking pan

Result:

13/11/2020
Spinach & Feta Shakshuka
My recipe
Ingredients:
1 onion, finely sliced
3 cloves garlic, finely sliced
1 teaspoon cumin seeds
400g frozen spinach, defrosted
1 teaspoon ground coriander
4 eggs
100g feta

Method:
Fry the onion in light oil with a few big pinches of salt until starting to brown
Add the garlic and cumin seeds and fry a couple more minutes
Add the spinach, fry a few minutes, check for salt and add the coriander
Make 4 indentations and crack an egg into each
Add a couple of spoons of water to the pan, sprinkle with feta, and cover with a lid until the eggs are cooked

Result:
Great!

07/11/2020
Potatoes in Stock and Cream
My Recipe
Ingredients:
5 Potatoes, Peeled & Sliced 6mm thick
Sprig of Thyme
40g Butter
1/4 Onion, finely sliced
1/2 Leek, sliced
300ml Stock
150ml Cream

Method:
Fry the onion and leek in half the butter until soft, then take off the heat
Meanwhile, fry the potatoes & thyme in the rest of the butter for 5-10 minutes
Add the stock to the potatoes, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until it is all absorbed
Top up with water as needed, and keep cooking with the cover on until the potatoes are cooked through
Add the cream, leek and onion to the potatoes
Check the seasoning, and finish in the oven for 15 minutes

Result:
Great!

31/10/2020
Moro Orange Cake
Moro - The Cookbook
Ingredients:
4 eggs, separated
160g caster sugar
150g ground almonds
finely grated zest of 2 oranges
juice of 5 oranges, preferably Seville
juice of 1 lemon (if not using Seville oranges)
1 stick cinnamon
caster sugar to taste

Method:
Heat oven to 180C and Line Pan.
Put a tablespoon of the caster sugar in with the egg whites
Beat the rest of the caster sugar with the egg yolks until pale
Mix in the almonds and zest
Beat the egg whites and sugar until stiff and then fold into the egg mixture
Bake for about 60-70 minutes until golden on top and firm to the touch

To make some orange syrup, gently simmer the orange juice, lemon juice, cinnamon and a handful of sugar for about five minutes. Taste for sugar – the syrup should be quite tart. Allow to cool

When the cake is ready, remove it from the oven and allow to cool before opening the spring-form tin
Transfer it to a plate and pierce holes in the top
Soak about up to about half of the syrup into the torta

Serve the remaining syrup on the side

Result:
Technical problems, but taste was good.
Looks nothing like the one on the guardian page
Rose and sank pretty severely, leaving it looking like a skateboarding bowl. Maybe less egg white....or more?...internet suggests both. Seemed overly full in the first place.
Overcooked on top and bottom. Probably should reduce cooking temp a bit


Did various syrups with 50g sugar, 500ml orange juice, 40ml lemon juice (reduced by, 35%, 50%, 60%, 70%). 50% reduced might be good for penetrating the cake, and 60% reduced would be good for serving with the cake.
Few flaked almonds or pistachios on top would help appearance
If I can't stop this collapsing, one option would be to cut the top off and flip it. Possibly also candied orange slices in the bottom which would then be the top.

28/10/2020
Chocolate Nemesis
River Cafe - Recipe in River Cafe Easy
Ingredients:
170g Chocolate 70%
2.5 eggs
112g butter
105g caster sugar

Method:
Eggs + 35g sugar beaten until volume quadruples
Melt chocolate and butter
Make syrup from remaining sugar + 50ml water
Add syrup to choc and let cool a bit
Add the chocolate to the eggs, and beat slowly until the mixture is combined
Pour into the tin
Bain marie at 120C until top is set and you can bring it a bit away from the sides (maybe 50 minutes for 25cm tin)
Took out of the oven after 45 minutes. Top was set, inner temp was 80C, could just about persuade it away from the sides of the tin
Chill completely in fridge

Result:
maybe could cook it slightly more - try until 85C
initially thought it wasn't cooked enough, as it was more like mousse when still warm. But after chilling in the fridge, it was good
should try with some really good chocolate

19/09/2020
Crepes
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V_okk5pOLp4
Ingredients:
20g Butter
55g Flour
1 egg
0.5g salt
5g sugar
120ml milk

Method:
Melt butter in the pan
Put everything else, but only a bit of the milk in a bowl and mix until smooth
Add the rest of the milk, enough to make it thin
Dump the melted butter in to the batter
Mix again, then cook your crepes
When cooking a crepe, dump the batter in one side of the pan and let it flow to the other, rather than dumping in the middle

Result:
Good. Tried with thick chocolate spread - about 1 part cream, 2 parts chocolate melted and stirred together

Generally very good, but maybe a bit too sweet and slightly too many egg yolks making it richer than necesary
Created a recipe, and adjusted the amounts for next time
08/09/2020
Beetroot Cured Salmon
300g salmon
1/2 small beetroot
Zest of 1 orange
Zest of 1 lemon
Large bunch of dill
32g kosher salt
30g sugar

Method:
Mix everything bar the dill and coat the salmon with the mixture.
Refrigerate for 24 hours, covered in plastic and weighted down with something.
Rinse the cure away, and let sit another half day in the fridge to allow salt to redistribute a bit.
Cover with finely chopped dill and serve.

Result:
Too salty, and not sure the beetroot brings much except color.
Should try again reducing either the salt or the cure time. (serious eats cure is 40g salt 25g sugar 900g salmon for 2 days)
White pepper is also a common addition. Coriander may also be good
07/09/2020
Salmon & Prawn Ravioli
https://www.notquitenigella.com/2008/11/17/ravioli-with-smoked-salmon-and-prawn
Ravioli:
200g smoked salmon
100g prawns
50g cream
Juice of 1/2 lemon
dill
black pepper

Sauce:
cream
large pinch of saffran
salt & pepper

Result:
Sauce was great. Filling I used was a bit too smoked salmony, and i want to try with ricotto. Created a recipe for this
02/09/2020
Maialino's Olive Oil (Orange) Cake
https://food52.com/recipes/26709-maialino-s-olive-oil-cake
Made this according to the recipe
Need to be careful with the batter as it wants to leak through even very small gaps in the pan. Had to use the cheaper pan as it sealed better

Result:
Was a bit too oily - some suggested to use better quality oil, the other option would be to reduce the oil
Could also have done with a bit more orange flavor
